title: Mum loses three kids and ex-husband in tragic plane crash
text:
"I had waved goodbye to them just a few hours earlier."

How to deal with the loss of a family member or someone you loved. Some helpful tips on how to navigate through life when you loose someone close to you.

How to deal with grief and the loss of a loved one 00:20:39

The last morning Karen would ever spend with her kids started like any other.

Morgan, a nine-year-old who suffered from severe epileptic seizures, and Logan, who was eight, had to be up early - even though it was the last day of school before the Thanksgiving holiday in November 2011.

The American mum-of-three let her youngest son Luke, a six-year-old who was autistic, stay in bed because he was already on holidays.

Karen remembers sitting on his bed and telling him he would be spending the holiday with his dad – who would fly a plane to collect them later.

“Unclothed, he jumped up and down cheerfully announcing, ‘Yeah I LOVE THANKSGIVING!’,” Karen first wrote on Still Standing Magazine.

“I said goodbye to them all later that day.

“Logan almost went out that night without saying goodbye. I told him to get back in the house and give me a hug and kiss, with no knowledge of what was yet to come.”

Karen with her three kids - Logan, Morgan and Luke. Source: Supplied

"It was a pitch-black night"

As Karen, who suffers from endometriosis, wasn’t feeling well, her nanny Jaleesa drove the three kids to a nearby private airport where her ex-husband Shawn was waiting in the small plane.

Both Karen and Shawn had worked for years as commercial pilots – it was where they had first met.

Shawn now worked for an aviation fire fighting company - and would be flying down in a small plane to collect the kids for the weekend.

As Karen would later watch in security footage, her kids greeted their dad around 6pm that night as the plane refuelled.

“While boarding the plane, Morgan created a scene and did not want to get on onboard,” Karen said.

“Shawn, to calm her, sat in the back of the aircraft with the children. They took off. It was a pitch-black night with no moon or visible horizon.”

The three kids were the most important thing in Karen's life. Source: Supplied

"Karen, there has been a plane crash!”

Karen woke up about an hour later, wondering why the kids hadn’t texted her to let her know that they had arrived like they normally did.

She sent a short text to Shawn to ask if everyone was OK but didn’t get a response.

The next thing Karen knew the phone was ringing off the hook.

No one ever used the house phone so she ignored it – but the person kept calling back.

“I was annoyed because I was trying to rest – what could possibly be that important?” she said.

“It was my nanny, Jaleesa. She was crying.

“Karen, there has been a plane crash!

“I was thinking to myself, 'OK, so planes crash every day, why are you telling me this?'”

The kids were spending the Thanksgiving holiday with their dad. Source: Supplied

"This has to be some kind of mistake"

It took Karen a few minutes to piece together the fact that her kids and ex had been on the plane that crashed.

She couldn’t make sense of the fact that no one had contacted her to let her know what was going on.

"I stumbled out of bed, dizzy and stunned,” she said.

“This can’t be true, I thought. It just can’t be. This has to be some kind of mistake.

“The ceiling seemed to swirl around my head, and the news hit me like ten thousand bullets.

“My only thought was 'MY KIDS ARE DEAD!'”

Within six minutes, Karen lost her entire family. Source: Supplied

"Just six minutes after take-off"

About an hour later, people started showing up at Karen’s house.

Through the crowd, Karen led the police into her living room.

They informed her that they were currently searching for survivors in the plane wreck – it had crashed just six minutes after take-off.

“They asked me lots of questions,” Karen said.

“I explained the custody arrangement that Shawn and I had.

“He would get the children every other weekend. Usually, he would fly to Mesa, from Safford, to pick up the kids and then would drive them home on Sunday.”

Tragically, no one survived the crash. Source: Supplied

“I knew it was Morgan"

Karen and Shawn’s divorce and custody battle had not been easy.

He had bitterly fought to take custody of the kids – and had been disappointed by the arrangement that only let me see them every other weekend.

Police prepared Karen to face the possibility that her ex had intentionally crashed the plane as a result.

But before she could able to process this – a child was confirmed dead in the crash.

“What was Morgan wearing?” Karen recalled being asked.

“They said that the dead child was possibly a female about nine years old. I knew it was Morgan.

“Hours later it was confirmed that the bodies of all six had been accounted for, and there were NO SURVIVORS.”

Just hours earlier the kids had all been at Karen's house. Source: Supplied

"I am not equipped to deal with this"

Karen sat in the living room that just hours ago had been filled with the activity of her three kids.

Their bags and shoes lay scattered by the door, the jacket she asked Logan to take was still on the shoe rack.

It seemed impossible that they were gone.

“So many times, I would ask God, ‘Why me? I am not equipped to deal with this’,” Karen said.

“I was dazed, confused, and could barely move because it felt as though cement had been poured all over my body.

“All I have left of my children are my memories and three small black boxes of ashes perched on a shelf in my bedroom closet.”

Now Karen had to plan her precious kids' funerals. Source: Supplied
description: "I had waved goodbye to them just a few hours earlier."
